Key Match Events: Jack Grealish netted the opener before Trent Alexander-Arnold bagged the second and Declan Rice the third.
Finland grabbed a late consolation goal in response.
Fredrik Jensen should have made it 1-1 shortly after the interval, spurning miles over from just yards out after Keskinen's excellent low cross.
Trent Alexander-Arnold set himself from the free-kick, about 25 yards out slightly to the left, and hits an absolute pearler to put England 2-0 up!
Ollie Watkins' surging run set up Declan Rice to make it three for England in the final six minutes,
Pre-Game Insights: England banished the disappointment of their midweek UEFA Nations League defeat to Greece as they ran out 3-1 winners over Finland to boost their automatic promotion hopes from League B Group 2.
Post-Match Reflections: England were spared by Finland's poor form in front of goal and ultimately rescued a comfortable cushion in the final moments as the hosts began to tire.
Trent Alexander-Arnold did well out there in the unfamiliar left-back position. He likely won't be the long-term solution out on the left, but he did more than a commendable job in Helsinki.
Miscellaneous Highlights: England were disappointed with the cheap manner of Finland's late consolation.
This so nearly went to Finland forward Keskinen, who was let down by his side's poor finishing.
The Augsburg forward, who has suffered a torrid few years in front of goal for both club and nation, blew the best opportunity of the game from Keskinen's fabulous cross.
Had it gone in, the game could have panned out quite differently.
Others: The Three Lions lulled after the opening goal as Finland created several opportunities to level the scoring.
Topi Keskinen, particularly, was a livewire for the hosts, but was let down by his team-mates' finishing.
England's defensive troubles throughout the evening came on their right-hand side, something not anticipated ahead of kick-off with Alexander-Arnold figuring in the unfamiliar left-back position.
